title: Deep Batch Active Learning by Diverse, Uncertain Gradient Lower Bounds
summary: This paper presents a new algorithm for batch active learning with deep neural network models. BADGE (Batch Active Learning by Diverse Gradient Embeddings) samples groups of points that are disparate and high-magnitude when represented in a hallucinated gradient space, trading off between diversity and uncertainty without requiring any hand-tuned hyperparameters.
methodology: The algorithm uses gradient embeddings to capture uncertainty about an example through the lens of gradients. It then selects a set of points by sampling via the k-MEANS++ initialization scheme, which tends to produce diverse batches similar to a k-Determinantal Point Process.
statistics: Proposition 1 shows that the norm of the gradient embedding is a lower bound on the norm of the loss gradient induced by the example with true label y with respect to the weights in the last layer.
research_outcomes: The paper shows that BADGE consistently performs as well or better than other approaches, making it a versatile option for practical active learning problems. It also demonstrates that switching between k-MEANS++ and k-DPP based sampling does not affect the active learner's statistical performance but greatly improves its computational performance.

title: AIM 2020 Challenge on Video Extreme Super-Resolution: Methods and Results
summary: This paper reviews the video extreme super-resolution challenge associated with the AIM 2020 workshop at ECCV 2020. The challenge focuses on upscaling videos with an extreme factor of 16, which results in more serious degradations that also affect the structural integrity of the videos. The paper discusses various methods for addressing this challenging task, including deep learning-based approaches and recurrent neural networks.
methodology: The challenge uses a dataset with paired high-quality DSLR camera (Canon 5D Mark IV) HR ground truth and LR source data obtained by downscaling the ground truth by factor 16. The methods discussed in the paper include deep learning-based approaches, recurrent neural networks, and other techniques for addressing the VSR problem.
research_outcomes: The challenge aims to super resolve the given input videos with an extremely large zooming factor of 16. The results show that various methods can achieve high-quality restoration, but there is still room for improvement in terms of fidelity and perceptual quality.

title: Non-Parametric Variational Inference with Graph Convolutional Networks for Gaussian Processes
summary: This paper proposes a novel approach to variational inference for Gaussian processes, leveraging graph convolutional networks to efficiently approximate the posterior distribution. The method significantly speeds up inference and often achieves more accurate results than previous methods.
methodology: The authors construct a variational distribution with which the inference for a data point takes information only from its K surrounding neighbors, making the ELBO highly decomposible. They then train Graph Convolutional Networks as a reusable model to identify variational parameters for each data point.
research_outcomes: The proposed method achieves better inference performance while using much less computation time compared to state-of-the-art methods.

title: The Microsoft 2017 Conversational Speech Recognition System
summary: This paper presents an updated version of the Microsoft conversational speech recognition system, which achieves a word error rate of 5.1% on the Switchboard evaluation set. The system combines recent developments in neural-network-based acoustic and language modeling to advance the state-of-the-art. Machine learning plays a central role in the methodology, with the use of convolutional neural networks (CNNs), bidirectional long short-term memory (BLSTM) models, and sequence training.
methodology: The system combines multiple acoustic models using a two-stage approach, followed by a word-level voting via confusion networks. The resulting system yields a 5.1% word error rate on the 2000 Switchboard evaluation set.
statistics: Maximum mutual information (MMI) as the discriminative objective function
research_outcomes: The paper presents an updated version of the Microsoft conversational speech recognition system, which achieves a word error rate of 5.1% on the Switchboard evaluation set.

title: Steady-State Planning in Expected Reward Multichain MDPs
summary: This paper explores the steady-state planning problem, which involves deriving decision-making policies for agents that satisfy constraints on their steady-state behavior. The authors propose a linear programming solution for multichain Markov Decision Processes (MDPs) and prove that optimal solutions yield stationary policies with rigorous guarantees of behavior.
methodology: The authors use linear programming to derive decision-making policies for agents in multichain MDPs, focusing on steady-state planning. They propose a novel approach that generalizes previous work by not imposing restrictions on the underlying MDP.
research_outcomes: The paper establishes a one-to-one correspondence between stationary policies and feasible solutions to linear programs for expected average reward criterion in multichain MDPs, providing provable performance and behavior guarantees for derived policies.

title: Recursive-NeRF: An Efficient and Dynamically Growing NeRF
summary: This paper presents Recursive-NeRF, a novel method for efficient and adaptive rendering of scenes using Neural Radiance Fields (NeRF). By recursively growing neural networks based on the complexity of the scene, Recursive-NeRF achieves significant gains in speed while providing high-quality view synthesis. The approach is complementary to existing methods such as NSVF and can be combined for further speed improvements.
methodology: Recursive-NeRF uses a recursive scene rendering method where early termination prevents further processing once output quality is good enough, achieving state-of-the-art novel view synthesis results with much reduced computation. A novel multi-stage dynamic growth method divides uncertain queries in the shallow part of the network and continues to refine them in differently grown deep networks.
statistics: The paper uses statistical methods for rendering and training neural networks, including hierarchical volume sampling and importance sampling.
research_outcomes: Recursive-NeRF achieves significant gains in speed while providing high-quality view synthesis. The approach is complementary to existing methods such as NSVF and can be combined for further speed improvements.

title: Fast IP Hopping Protocol SDI Implementation
summary: This paper proposes a new approach to protect against Distributed Denial of Service attacks and traffic eavesdropping in TCP/IP networks. The method, called IP Fast Hopping, introduces a dynamic mapping of server's address on a large set of temporary addresses, hiding the physical location of protected servers from unauthorized clients.
methodology: The paper proposes an alternative approach to DDoS attacks resistance via randomization of network address by introducing a specific addressing policy. The method is based on a mathematical model of network traffic traversing with decomposition mapping of instantaneous traffic intensity.
research_outcomes: The proposed method provides a way to attenuate or completely block malicious traffic in the network without analyzing and processing network traffic.

title: From Data Acquisition to Data Fusion: A Comprehensive Review and a Roadmap for the Identification of Activities of Daily Living Using Mobile Devices
summary: This paper presents a comprehensive review of sensor data fusion techniques for identifying activities of daily living (ADLs) using mobile devices. The authors focus on the state-of-the-art in sensor fusion, highlighting its importance in improving algorithm reliability and addressing mobile device constraints.
methodology: The paper proposes a new classification of sensors embedded in off-the-shelf mobile devices, identifying different techniques related to data acquisition, processing, and imputation. It also reviews data fusion techniques for off-the-shelf mobile devices and presents examples of sensor data fusion applications.
research_outcomes: The authors present a comprehensive review of sensor data fusion techniques, highlighting their importance in identifying ADLs using mobile devices. They propose a new classification of sensors and review data fusion techniques for off-the-shelf mobile devices.

title: Joint Bayesian Gaussian Discriminant Analysis for Speaker Verification
summary: This paper presents a novel approach to speaker verification using Joint Bayesian (JB) Gaussian discriminant analysis. The authors apply JB, originally proposed for face verification, to the speaker verification task and make three contributions: employing exact statistics in EM iterations, simultaneous diagonalization of within-class and between-class covariance matrices, and comparing similarities and differences with various Gaussian PLDAs.
methodology: The authors use a probabilistic generative model, Joint Bayesian (JB) Gaussian discriminant analysis, to address the challenges in speaker verification. They employ EM iterations with exact statistics and simultaneous diagonalization of covariance matrices to improve performance.
research_outcomes: The paper presents three main contributions: employing exact statistics in EM iterations, simultaneous diagonalization of within-class and between-class covariance matrices, and comparing similarities and differences with various Gaussian PLDAs. The authors also conduct extensive experiments on NIST SRE10 core condition 5, empirically validating the superiority of JB.

title: Learning Agent-Aware Affordances for Closed-Loop Interaction with Articulated Objects
summary: This paper proposes a novel closed-loop control pipeline that integrates manipulation priors from affordance estimation with sampling-based whole-body control. The pipeline is agent-aware, meaning it takes into account the robot's capabilities and embodiment, and outperforms state-of-the-art counterparts in tasks such as opening and closing an oven door.
methodology: The proposed pipeline combines affordance estimation with sampling-based whole-body control. Affordance estimation is performed using a neural network that predicts point-wise interaction scores, which are then used to select a favorable end-effector interaction pose. The sampling-based controller generates joint velocity commands based on the selected interaction pose.
statistics: The paper uses statistical methods for affordance estimation and control policy optimization.
research_outcomes: The proposed pipeline outperforms state-of-the-art counterparts in tasks such as opening and closing an oven door, with success rates of over 70%.

title: Explore Semantic Pixel Sets Based Local Pattern with Entropy Information for Face Recognition and Application in Back Propagation
summary: This paper presents a novel approach to face recognition using semantic pixel sets based local patterns with entropy information. The method combines the Local Binary Pattern (LBP) operator with a semantic pixel set of entropy information, which is used as input for classification using back propagation networks. The results show a high recognition rate of 98%.
methodology: The methodology involves dividing the sample data into NxM zones and calculating the feature value of each zone. The LBP method is used to extract features from each image, followed by the semantic pixel set method to extract entropy information.
research_outcomes: The paper presents a high recognition rate of 98% using the proposed approach.

title: Psychological Bidirectional Influences of Information Sampling and Concept Learning
summary: This paper investigates how humans actively sample information from sources expected to provide behaviorally relevant information, developing a computational model called Sampling Emergent Attention (SEA) that reflects this effect. The model consists of two interacting components and predicts classic behavioral effects associated with selective attention.
methodology: The authors develop a computational model, SEA, designed to reflect the effect of humans actively sampling information from sources expected to provide behaviorally relevant information.
research_outcomes: The model predicts classic behavioral effects associated with selective attention and closely resembles patterns of human eye movements.

title: Burn image segmentation based on Mask Regions with Convolutional Neural Network deep learning framework: more accurate and more convenient
summary: This paper proposes a novel method for burn image segmentation using the Mask R-CNN deep learning framework, achieving more accurate and convenient results compared to traditional methods. The authors employed state-of-the-art techniques, including Atrous Convolution in Feature Pyramid Network (FPN), to segment burn wounds in images.
methodology: The proposed method employs a deep learning framework based on Mask R-CNN, with modifications to adapt to the dataset and improve training speed. The authors used Atrous Convolution in FPN as the backbone network.
research_outcomes: The R101FA backbone network achieved the highest accuracy of 84.51% in 150 pictures, with the best segmentation effect in superficial, superficial thickness, and deep partial thickness burn wounds.

title: Phase Distribution in Probabilistic Movement Primitives
summary: This paper investigates a method to temporally align observations for learning ProMPs, maximizing spatial structure information while maintaining smooth phase velocity. The proposed system recognizes and reproduces human movements using probabilistic movement primitives.
methodology: The authors propose a two-step procedure for estimating phase profile parameters that minimize variability on w. They use empirical estimators to obtain distributions for w and φ(t).
research_outcomes: The proposed method is demonstrated to be effective in recognizing and reproducing human movements.

title: Design Principles for Data Analysis
summary: This paper introduces design principles for data analysis, which are complementary to statistical thinking. The authors propose six principles: data matching, exhaustive, reproducibility, transparency, interpretability, and explainability. They argue that these principles can help induce variation in data analyses and provide a framework for teaching students how to build data analyses using formal design principles.
methodology: The authors use a combination of statistical thinking and design thinking to introduce the design principles for data analysis. They describe an example in the classroom for how the design principles can be mapped to data analyses in a quantitative, objective, and informative manner.
research_outcomes: The paper introduces six design principles for data analysis: data matching, exhaustive, reproducibility, transparency, interpretability, and explainability. The authors provide empirical evidence of variation in principles within and between both producers and consumers of data analyses.

title: UrduFake@FIRE2020: Shared Track on Fake News Identification in Urdu
summary: This paper presents the first shared task at FIRE 2020 on fake news detection in the Urdu language. The study uses machine learning methods, including BERT-based approaches, to identify fake news and achieves an F-score value of 0.90.
methodology: The paper employs a binary classification task using various machine learning methods, including feature-based traditional machine learning and neural network techniques.
statistics: F1-macro score is used as the evaluation metric to accommodate class imbalance
research_outcomes: The best performing system achieved an F-score value of 0.90, showing that the BERT-based approach outperforms other machine learning classifiers.

title: System Identification with Student’s t-Process Dynamical Model
summary: This paper proposes a Student's t-process dynamical model (TPDM) for state space modeling, which is an extension of the TPLVM. The TPDM is applied to the problem of satellite orbit estimation, where it successfully estimates the true position of the satellite from observed information.
methodology: The paper uses a particle filter-based approach for online Bayesian estimation, which treats the parameter vector as a dynamical variable.
research_outcomes: The TPDM is shown to be effective in estimating satellite orbits from observed information.

title: A High-Quality Multilingual Dataset for Structured Documentation Translation
summary: This paper presents a high-quality multilingual dataset for structured documentation translation, which advances research on localization of structured text. The dataset is built from the online documentation of an enterprise software platform and includes XML-structured parallel text segments in 16 languages. Machine learning-based translation models are used to improve translation accuracy, and the beam search accurately generates XML structures.
methodology: The dataset is built by collecting parallel text segments from the online documentation of an enterprise software platform, using a pairwise sequence alignment algorithm for each bilingually-aligned file. The XML elements are well formed and translators keep the same tagging structure as much as their languages allow it.
research_outcomes: The experiments show that learning to translate with the XML tags improves translation accuracy, and the beam search accurately generates XML structures. The dataset can also serve as a corpus for domain adaptation research.
sources_of_inspiration: Michel and Neubig, 2018; Bawden et al., 2018; Müller et al., 2018

title: Part Attentioned Fine-Grained Categorization Using Context Sensitive Flow
summary: This paper proposes a novel multiple scales attention fusing convolutional neural network for fine-grained image recognition. The proposed method, FFCSnet, consists of two main components: a new part feature fused attention net and a context sensitive loss. It achieves state-of-the-art performance on two challenging fine-grained image recognition datasets, CUB Birds and Stanford Cars.
methodology: The proposed method uses a self-attention study network (SASN) to compute region attention and a context-sensitive module to take advantage of deeper and wider network features. The whole scale feature maps are added element-wise to the part feature maps, mixing low-level features with high-level features.
research_outcomes: The proposed method achieves state-of-the-art performance on two challenging fine-grained image recognition datasets, CUB Birds and Stanford Cars.

title: CU-UD: text-mining drug and chemical-protein interactions with ensembles of BERT-based models
summary: This paper presents an ensemble system for text-mining drug and chemical-protein interactions using BERT-based models. The system combines the outputs of individual models using majority voting and multilayer perceptron, achieving state-of-the-art performance on the DrugProt task in BioCreative VII.
methodology: The paper uses an ensemble approach combining multiple BERT-based language representation models to achieve better predictive performance. The system considers two entity tagging schemes and employs a class-weighted loss function, majority voting, and meta-learning method to mitigate the unbalance in the training dataset.
research_outcomes: The paper presents state-of-the-art performance on the DrugProt task in BioCreative VII, with an F1 score of 0.8902 for the ANTAGONIST relation and 0.8570 for the INHIBITOR relation.

title: Fast Evaluation of Real and Complex Polynomials
summary: This paper proposes a novel algorithm for quickly evaluating polynomials, with a focus on improving the speed without compromising precision. The algorithm is designed for repeated single-point evaluations and can also be used as an embarrassingly parallel multipoint evaluator.
methodology: The proposed algorithm uses a divide and conquer recursion to evaluate polynomials at multiple points simultaneously, with a cost of O((d + k) log d log kd).
research_outcomes: The paper presents a detailed analysis of the complexity and accuracy of the proposed algorithm, showing that it outperforms existing methods in many cases.

title: Statistically Profiling Biases in Natural Language Reasoning Datasets and Models
summary: This paper proposes a light-weight statistical profiling framework, ICQ (I-See-Cue), to identify biases in natural language reasoning datasets and models. The framework automatically identifies possible biases in multiple-choice NLU datasets without the need for additional test cases, and evaluates through blackbox testing the extent to which models may exploit these biases.
methodology: The ICQ framework consists of three phases: data filtering, cue discovery, and model probing. In the data filtering phase, it extracts from the dataset those problem instances that contain a given linguistic feature. In the cue discovery phase, it identifies the possible cues in this dataset. Finally, in the model probing phase, it does two tests: 'accuracy test' and 'distribution test'.
statistics: mean squared error (MSE) and Jensen-Shannon Divergence
research_outcomes: The paper makes several contributions, including providing a light-weight but effective method to uncover statistical biases and cues in NL reasoning datasets, proposing two simple tests to quantitatively and visually assess whether a given model has taken advantage of a spurious cue when making predictions, and evaluating the statistical bias issues comprehensively on 10 popular NLR datasets and 4 models.

title: Proximal Distilled Evolutionary Reinforcement Learning
summary: This paper proposes a novel algorithm called Proximal Distilled Evolutionary Reinforcement Learning (PDERL) that integrates evolution and learning to enhance each other. PDERL uses learning-based variation operators that compensate for the simplicity of genetic representation, addressing the scalability problem of Genetic Algorithms (GAs).
methodology: The proposed method combines Evolutionary Reinforcement Learning (ERL) with learning-based genetic operators to improve the performance and scalability of GAs.
research_outcomes: PDERL outperforms ERL, PPO, and TD3 in all five robot locomotion environments from the OpenAI gym.
sources_of_inspiration: Evolutionary Reinforcement Learning (ERL) framework by Khadka and Tumer (2018)
DDPG algorithm by Lillicrap et al. (2015)

title: Real-Time Social Network-Based Knowledge Discovery System for Decision Making
summary: This paper presents a real-time social network-based knowledge discovery system that uses natural language processing and text mining techniques to automatically interpret user opinions about venues. The system is designed for decision-making, allowing users to quickly identify positive, negative, or neutral thoughts about foods, beverages, and venues.
methodology: The system uses a natural language processing pipeline to organize and correct user recommendations, followed by text mining techniques to classify opinions as positive, negative, or neutral. The organized data are then classified according to feelings and thoughts, and the system identifies whether a venue near the user's location was liked.
statistics: Classification accuracy of 84.49% for Turkish and 95% for English
research_outcomes: The developed system achieves high classification accuracy and can be used as a baseline for sentiment analysis in social networks.

title: Automated Maxillofacial Segmentation in Panoramic Dental X-Ray Images Using an Efficient Encoder-Decoder Network
summary: This paper proposes a deep learning-based approach for automated maxillofacial segmentation in panoramic dental X-ray images. The proposed model, EED-Net, achieves better accuracy and speed trade-offs than state-of-the-art methods, making it suitable for real-time applications.
methodology: The paper proposes an efficient encoder-decoder network (EED-Net) for maxillofacial segmentation. The model consists of three modules: a feature encoder, a corresponding decoder, and a multipath feature extractor. The encoder uses residual blocks to obtain deeper features, while the decoder employs skip connections to pass low-resolution texture and location information.
statistics: The paper uses statistical methods to evaluate the performance of EED-Net on the maxillofacial dataset.
research_outcomes: The proposed model achieves better overall performance than state-of-the-art real-time semantic segmentation models, demonstrating its efficiency for maxillofacial segmentation.
